_link.title: I can describe compartmentalisation and explain its importance for cells

toLevel2.question: What is compartmentalisation in a cell?

options.text: The division of a cell into membrane-bound organelles
The process of cell division into two daughter cells
options.explanation: Cell division is a separate process; compartmentalisation refers to organelles within a single cell.

options.text: The movement of substances across the plasma membrane
options.explanation: Membrane transport is a different concept from compartmentalisation.

options.text: The storage of DNA inside the cytoplasm
options.explanation: Compartmentalisation involves membrane-bound organelles, not just DNA storage in the cytoplasm.

toLevel2.question: What do membrane-bound organelles maintain within a cell?

options.text: Their own internal environment
A connection to the external environment
options.explanation: Organelle membranes separate the internal environment from the surrounding cytoplasm, not the external environment.

options.text: A uniform pH throughout the whole cell
options.explanation: Compartmentalisation allows different organelles to maintain different internal conditions, not uniform pH.

options.text: The same conditions as the cytoplasm
options.explanation: The purpose of compartmentalisation is to maintain conditions different from the cytoplasm.

toLevel2.question: Why is compartmentalisation important for large eukaryotic cells?

options.text: It allows many different chemical reactions to occur efficiently at the same time
It prevents the cell from needing a nucleus
options.explanation: Eukaryotic cells have a nucleus; compartmentalisation supports efficient reactions, not the absence of a nucleus.

options.text: It makes the cell smaller so reactions happen faster
options.explanation: Compartmentalisation concentrates reactants within organelles rather than shrinking the cell.

options.text: It stops the cell from producing any waste products
options.explanation: Compartmentalisation organises reactions but does not eliminate waste production.

toLevel2.question: How does enclosing reactants in a small organelle increase the rate of reaction?

options.text: The molecules are concentrated in a smaller volume, making collisions more likely
The organelle heats up the molecules so they move faster
options.explanation: Organelles do not heat molecules; concentration in a small space increases collision frequency.

options.text: The organelle membrane pushes molecules together forcefully
options.explanation: The membrane contains molecules but does not push them; concentration increases natural collision rates.

options.text: The organelle removes all water so only reactants remain
options.explanation: Organelles contain water; it is the reduced volume that concentrates reactants.

toLevel2.question: Which type of cell relies on compartmentalisation to carry out specialised functions?

options.text: Eukaryotic cells
Prokaryotic cells
options.explanation: Prokaryotic cells lack membrane-bound organelles and therefore do not rely on compartmentalisation.

options.text: Viral particles
options.explanation: Viruses are not cells and do not have organelles or compartmentalisation.

options.text: Red blood cells
options.explanation: Mature red blood cells lack most organelles; compartmentalisation is a general feature of eukaryotic cells.

toLevel2.statement: Compartmentalisation refers to the division of a cell into membrane-bound organelles, each with its own internal environment.
toLevel2.explanation: This is the correct definition of compartmentalisation in cell biology.

toLevel2.statement: Prokaryotic cells rely heavily on compartmentalisation because they have many membrane-bound organelles.
toLevel2.explanation: Prokaryotic cells lack membrane-bound organelles and therefore do not have compartmentalisation.

toLevel2.sentence: Compartmentalisation is the division of a cell into {{blank:1}} organelles, each maintaining its own internal {{blank:2}}.
By enclosing reactants in a smaller {{blank:1}}, molecules are more {{blank:2}} and collisions occur more frequently.
Without compartmentalisation, a large {{blank:1}} cell would not be able to carry out many different chemical reactions {{blank:2}} at the same time.

toLevel3.question: Why would spreading reactants throughout a large cell reduce the rate of chemical reactions?

options.text: Molecules would be too spread out to collide frequently enough for reactions to occur
Large cells do not contain any enzymes to speed up reactions
options.explanation: Large cells contain enzymes; the issue is that reactants are too dispersed for frequent collisions.

options.text: Molecules in large cells move more slowly than in small cells
options.explanation: Molecular speed depends on temperature, not cell size; concentration determines collision frequency.

options.text: Chemical reactions cannot occur inside cells larger than a certain size
options.explanation: Reactions can occur in large cells, but compartmentalisation is needed for efficiency.

toLevel3.question: How does compartmentalisation link cell size to the need for organelles?

options.text: Larger cells need organelles to concentrate reactants, which would otherwise be too dilute in a big volume
Larger cells need organelles only for storage purposes
options.explanation: Organelles serve many functions beyond storage, including concentrating reactants for efficient reactions.

options.text: Smaller cells need more organelles because they have less space
options.explanation: It is larger cells that benefit most from compartmentalisation to maintain reaction efficiency.

options.text: Cell size has no relationship to the number of organelles needed
options.explanation: Larger cells require compartmentalisation to keep reactant concentrations at levels where reactions are efficient.

toLevel3.question: Why can different organelles maintain different internal conditions within the same cell?

options.text: Each organelle is enclosed by its own membrane, which separates its contents from the cytoplasm
The cytoplasm actively changes conditions around each organelle
options.explanation: It is the organelle membrane that maintains the distinct environment, not changes in the cytoplasm.

options.text: All organelles share the same conditions as the cytoplasm
options.explanation: Compartmentalisation specifically allows organelles to have different conditions from the cytoplasm.

options.text: The nucleus controls the conditions inside every organelle directly
options.explanation: Each organelle maintains its own environment through its membrane, not through direct nuclear control.

toLevel3.question: A student explains that compartmentalisation helps cells because it keeps all molecules in one place. What is wrong with this explanation?

options.text: Compartmentalisation separates different types of molecules into different organelles, not one place
The explanation is completely correct and needs no correction
options.explanation: Compartmentalisation distributes molecules across multiple organelles, not into one location.

options.text: Compartmentalisation removes molecules from the cell entirely
options.explanation: Compartmentalisation keeps molecules within organelles inside the cell.

options.text: The explanation is wrong because compartmentalisation only occurs in prokaryotes
options.explanation: Compartmentalisation is a feature of eukaryotic cells, not prokaryotes.

toLevel3.question: What advantage does compartmentalisation provide when a cell needs to carry out reactions requiring different pH levels?

options.text: Different organelles can maintain different pH levels behind their membranes
The cell can change its overall pH to suit each reaction one at a time
options.explanation: Compartmentalisation allows simultaneous reactions at different pH levels, not sequential pH changes.

options.text: All reactions in a cell must occur at the same pH regardless
options.explanation: Different organelles such as lysosomes maintain acidic environments distinct from the neutral cytoplasm.

options.text: pH is not relevant to any chemical reactions inside cells
options.explanation: Many enzymes require specific pH levels to function optimally.

toLevel3.question: How does compartmentalisation benefit a cell that carries out both photosynthesis and cellular respiration?

options.text: It separates these processes into chloroplasts and mitochondria, preventing interference between them
It combines both processes in the same organelle for greater efficiency
options.explanation: Photosynthesis and respiration occur in different organelles with different internal conditions.

options.text: It stops the cell from performing respiration when photosynthesis is occurring
options.explanation: Both processes can occur simultaneously because they are in separate compartments.

options.text: It has no benefit because these processes do not need to be separated
options.explanation: Separating these processes allows each to occur under optimal conditions.

toLevel3.statement: Compartmentalisation allows different chemical reactions to occur simultaneously under different conditions within the same cell.
toLevel3.explanation: Each membrane-bound organelle can maintain distinct conditions, enabling multiple different reactions at once.

toLevel3.sentence: In a large cell without organelles, reactant molecules would be too {{blank:1}} to collide frequently, so reactions would be {{blank:2}}.
Compartmentalisation allows organelles such as {{blank:1}} to maintain an acidic internal environment that is different from the {{blank:2}} cytoplasm.
Photosynthesis and cellular respiration can occur at the same time because they are separated into different {{blank:1}}, each with its own optimal {{blank:2}}.

toLevel4.question: A scientist creates an artificial cell with no internal membranes and places enzymes for ten different reactions inside. What problem would you predict?

options.text: Reactants would be diluted across the whole volume, reducing reaction rates and causing interference between pathways
All ten reactions would proceed faster because enzymes are close together
options.explanation: Without compartmentalisation, reactants would be diluted and different pathways could interfere with each other.

options.text: The enzymes would not function because they need a nucleus to work
options.explanation: Enzymes function based on their environment (pH, substrate concentration), not the presence of a nucleus.

options.text: Nothing would go wrong because compartmentalisation is not necessary for reactions
options.explanation: Without compartmentalisation, reactions would be less efficient due to diluted reactants and potential interference.

toLevel4.question: Lysosomes maintain a pH of about 5, while the cytoplasm has a pH of about 7. How does compartmentalisation make this possible?

options.text: The lysosome membrane separates the acidic interior from the neutral cytoplasm
The cytoplasm actively neutralises the acid leaking from lysosomes
options.explanation: The lysosome membrane prevents acid from leaking; compartmentalisation maintains the pH difference.

options.text: Lysosomes are located outside the cell where they do not affect cytoplasmic pH
options.explanation: Lysosomes are intracellular organelles enclosed by membranes within the cell.

options.text: The nucleus regulates the pH of every organelle to keep them identical
options.explanation: Different organelles maintain different pH levels; the nucleus does not equalise them.

toLevel4.question: A drug damages organelle membranes in a cell, causing their contents to leak into the cytoplasm. What effect would this have on the cell?

options.text: Reactions that require specific conditions would fail because the optimal environment inside organelles is lost
The cell would function normally because all reactions can occur in the cytoplasm
options.explanation: Many reactions require specific conditions maintained by organelle membranes.

options.text: The cell would immediately split into two new cells
options.explanation: Membrane damage does not trigger cell division; it disrupts cellular function.

options.text: Only the nucleus would be affected because it is the only membrane-bound organelle
options.explanation: Many organelles have membranes, and damage to any of them would affect their specific functions.

toLevel4.question: A student models compartmentalisation using separate beakers, each containing different solutions. How does this accurately represent what happens in a cell?

options.text: Each beaker represents an organelle with its own internal conditions, just as organelle membranes separate different environments
The beakers should all contain the same solution to represent the uniform cytoplasm
options.explanation: The point of compartmentalisation is that different organelles have different internal environments.

options.text: The beakers should be open-topped to represent free exchange of materials
options.explanation: Organelle membranes selectively control what enters and exits, similar to sealed or covered containers.

options.text: Using beakers is invalid because glass is not the same as a biological membrane
options.explanation: Models do not need to be identical to the real thing; the beakers represent the concept of separation.

toLevel4.question: Prokaryotic cells are generally much smaller than eukaryotic cells and lack membrane-bound organelles. How does their small size compensate for the lack of compartmentalisation?

options.text: In a small volume, reactants are naturally concentrated enough for efficient reactions without organelles
Prokaryotic cells do not carry out any chemical reactions
options.explanation: Prokaryotic cells carry out many chemical reactions including respiration and protein synthesis.

options.text: Prokaryotic cells borrow organelles from nearby eukaryotic cells
options.explanation: Cells do not share organelles; prokaryotes function without them due to their small size.

options.text: Prokaryotic cells are so small that they do not need any molecules at all
options.explanation: All cells contain molecules; the small size of prokaryotes naturally concentrates their reactants.

toLevel4.question: A mitochondrion has an inner membrane with many folds. How does this relate to compartmentalisation?

options.text: The folds create additional compartments that increase the surface area for reactions involved in energy release
The folds reduce the surface area so fewer reactions occur
options.explanation: Folds increase surface area, which increases the rate of reactions.

options.text: The folds are storage spaces for glucose molecules
options.explanation: The folds (cristae) provide surface area for the enzymes involved in cellular respiration.

options.text: The folds serve no functional purpose and are a random structural feature
options.explanation: The folds are an adaptation that maximises the efficiency of energy-releasing reactions.

toLevel4.question: If a cell's lysosomes lost their membranes, what would be the most immediate consequence?

options.text: Digestive enzymes would leak into the cytoplasm and could damage other cell structures
The cell would produce more energy because enzymes are released
options.explanation: Lysosomal enzymes digest materials; releasing them would damage the cell, not produce more energy.

options.text: The cell would begin photosynthesis using the released enzymes
options.explanation: Lysosomal enzymes are digestive, not photosynthetic.

options.text: Nothing would change because lysosomal enzymes work at all pH levels
options.explanation: Lysosomal enzymes work best at acidic pH; in the neutral cytoplasm they would still cause damage to structures.

toLevel4.sentence: Prokaryotic cells lack {{blank:1}} but their small size means reactants are naturally {{blank:2}} enough for efficient reactions.
If lysosomal membranes were damaged, digestive {{blank:1}} would leak into the cytoplasm and could {{blank:2}} other cell structures.
The inner membrane folds of mitochondria create additional {{blank:1}} that increase the surface area available for {{blank:2}} reactions.

toLevel5.question: A student argues that prokaryotic cells are less successful than eukaryotic cells because they lack compartmentalisation. Analyse this argument.

options.text: This is flawed because prokaryotes are extremely successful organisms; their small size compensates for lacking compartmentalisation
This is correct because eukaryotic cells are always more efficient than prokaryotic cells
options.explanation: Prokaryotes are highly successful and thrive in diverse environments despite lacking compartmentalisation.

options.text: This is correct because prokaryotes cannot carry out any metabolic reactions
options.explanation: Prokaryotes carry out many metabolic reactions efficiently due to their small cell volume.

options.text: This is flawed because prokaryotes actually have extensive compartmentalisation
options.explanation: Prokaryotes lack membrane-bound organelles; the argument is flawed because success is not determined by compartmentalisation alone.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate the statement: 'Compartmentalisation is the single most important feature that distinguishes eukaryotic cells from prokaryotic cells.'

options.text: It is a key distinguishing feature but calling it the single most important oversimplifies the many differences between these cell types
It is completely correct because no other differences exist between eukaryotes and prokaryotes
options.explanation: Other differences include cell size, DNA organisation, and ribosome size.

options.text: It is incorrect because prokaryotes also have compartmentalisation
options.explanation: Prokaryotes lack membrane-bound organelles and do not have compartmentalisation.

options.text: It is irrelevant because compartmentalisation has no functional significance
options.explanation: Compartmentalisation is functionally significant but is not the only distinguishing feature.

toLevel5.question: Why might a very large cell that lacks compartmentalisation be unable to survive?

options.text: Reactants would be too dilute for reactions to occur at rates fast enough to sustain the cell
The cell would be too heavy to remain in one place
options.explanation: Cell weight is not the limiting factor; reaction efficiency is the critical issue.

options.text: The cell membrane would not be strong enough to hold the cell together
options.explanation: Membrane strength relates to structural integrity, not the efficiency of internal reactions.

options.text: Large cells always divide before they can grow too big
options.explanation: While cells do divide, the question asks about the consequence of lacking compartmentalisation in a large cell.

toLevel5.question: A researcher proposes creating artificial compartments inside prokaryotic cells to make them function like eukaryotes. Evaluate this idea.

options.text: It is theoretically interesting but would require overcoming the challenge of maintaining stable membranes and correct sorting of molecules
It is impossible because prokaryotes cannot contain any membranes at all
options.explanation: Prokaryotes have a plasma membrane; the challenge is creating stable internal compartments.

options.text: It would be simple because adding membranes inside a cell is straightforward
options.explanation: Creating functional compartments requires complex sorting and transport systems, not just membranes.

options.text: It has already been done successfully and prokaryotes now have organelles
options.explanation: This has not been fully achieved; it remains an area of synthetic biology research.

toLevel5.question: The endosymbiotic theory suggests that mitochondria and chloroplasts were once free-living prokaryotes. How does this relate to compartmentalisation?

options.text: Engulfing prokaryotes created new membrane-bound compartments within the host cell, increasing compartmentalisation
Endosymbiosis eliminated compartmentalisation by merging all membranes into one
options.explanation: Endosymbiosis added new compartments by retaining the engulfed organisms as separate organelles.

options.text: Endosymbiosis has no connection to compartmentalisation because it only involves DNA transfer
options.explanation: Endosymbiosis directly created new membrane-bound compartments within the host cell.

options.text: Compartmentalisation existed in prokaryotes before endosymbiosis occurred
options.explanation: Prokaryotes lack membrane-bound organelles; endosymbiosis contributed to the compartmentalisation seen in eukaryotes.

toLevel5.question: A student writes: 'Compartmentalisation is unnecessary because enzymes alone can control which reactions occur in a cell.' Evaluate this claim.

options.text: Enzymes are important but compartmentalisation also controls reactant concentration and prevents harmful reactions from occurring in the wrong location
The student is correct because enzymes are the only factor controlling cellular reactions
options.explanation: Enzymes control reaction specificity, but compartmentalisation also controls concentration and prevents harmful cross-reactions.

options.text: The student is correct because compartmentalisation plays no role in reaction control
options.explanation: Compartmentalisation is critical for maintaining optimal conditions and separating incompatible reactions.

options.text: The student is incorrect because enzymes do not exist inside cells
options.explanation: Enzymes are present inside cells; the issue is that enzymes alone are not sufficient without compartmentalisation.

toLevel5.question: How does compartmentalisation contribute to the efficiency of protein synthesis and processing in a eukaryotic cell?

options.text: Proteins are synthesised at ribosomes on the rough ER, then processed in the Golgi apparatus, with each organelle providing optimal conditions for its step
All steps of protein production occur in the nucleus without needing other organelles
options.explanation: The nucleus contains DNA but protein synthesis and processing involve ribosomes, ER and the Golgi apparatus.

options.text: Compartmentalisation slows protein synthesis because materials must be transported between organelles
options.explanation: While transport is needed, compartmentalisation ensures each step occurs efficiently under optimal conditions.

options.text: Proteins are made and processed entirely in the cytoplasm without organelle involvement
options.explanation: While free ribosomes exist in the cytoplasm, many proteins require processing through the ER and Golgi apparatus.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate whether compartmentalisation could be considered a disadvantage for eukaryotic cells in any situation.

options.text: Yes, because maintaining organelle membranes and transport systems requires energy, which is a metabolic cost
No, compartmentalisation is always advantageous with absolutely no drawbacks
options.explanation: Maintaining membranes and intracellular transport systems requires energy, representing a metabolic cost.

options.text: Yes, because compartmentalisation prevents any reactions from occurring
options.explanation: Compartmentalisation organises reactions rather than preventing them.

options.text: No, because prokaryotes would also benefit from compartmentalisation but cannot evolve it
options.explanation: Prokaryotes function efficiently without compartmentalisation due to their small size.

toLevel5.sentence: Endosymbiosis contributed to compartmentalisation by creating new {{blank:1}} compartments when ancestral eukaryotic cells engulfed {{blank:2}}.
A potential disadvantage of compartmentalisation is the {{blank:1}} cost of maintaining organelle membranes and intracellular {{blank:2}} systems.
